dspace-development.title: Update the TLS cipher suite support for the Symplectic Elements server environments

comments.body:
After requesting support from @kayiwa, updating the TLS cipher suite proved to have successfully ensure that Items can be deposited from Elements into the OAR:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1443986/98011958-88283a80-1dc6-11eb-81e7-df09440d2b42.png)

I am still trying to troubleshoot authorization policies for the deposited Items (as an administrator, I can accept these into a workflow, but cannot publish them).

comments.body:
So idk about this tool. here's a blog post about what it does / doesn't do: https://accesslint.com/blog/accesslint-github-marketplace-launch/

It seems like if we really want to do an accessibility CI check we'll need to actually run the site (i guess using docker somehow) as part of ci and run lighthouse on it.

pulfalight.title: Ensure that the "ask a question" form is fully accessible

comments.body: where can someone find this form on the site?

pulfalight.title: Integrate accessibility testing into the continuous integration workflow

comments.body:
This is built on axe-core and looks pretty easy to set up: https://thoughtbot.com/blog/introducing-accesslint-web-accessibility-testing-in-ci

edit: nevermind, this project has been archived.

Deprecation note on the project recommends https://github.com/apps/accesslint github integration

As I said on #450 , that accesslint tool doesn't render templates; it really only reviews html-formatted code.

Lighthouse ci documentation: https://github.com/GoogleChrome/lighthouse-ci/blob/master/docs/getting-started.md
and someone's blog post: https://josephkhan.me/run-lighthouse-performance-audits/

The lighthouse route will only be possible if we can configure a running production app in circleci.

The axe-core tool integrates into javascript tests. We currently don't have any javascript tests, but even if we did they don't render our rails pages. The assumption of that tool is that you're running it against a javascript front-end.

I'm not sure we have a great option here.

comments.body: We're moving this to the backlog for now, we've found we're unable to implement this at the moment. For now users will have to redirect to the Aeon page as they currently do. Maybe @sdellis can provide some background as to what the blockers were for the implementation of this?

The Aeon API updates that would likely allow us to submit requests via POST with an auth token was scheduled for Q3 earlier this year. Now their site says Q4. I say "likely" because there seems to be no itemized list of what new API actions they are adding. This was a "wishlist" feature if things fell into place in time, but it's not doable at the moment.

pulfalight.title: Display folder number ranges at the parent level in addition to the extent note that says however many folders or containers are represented by the parent level

comments.body: @faithc @apferrar Can you look at what exists in the staging site and point us to what's wrong? We're a little confused.
I think this issue is resolved now? @apferrar?

Though I did spot another issue looking into this. The physloc text notes associated with container records, which note where in the stacks an item is located, should not display on the site. This is for staff use only. For example, see: https://pulfalight-staging.princeton.edu/catalog/aspace_C1491_c5621. "D-zone" should not display on the site. Should another issue be created for this?

pulfalight.title: Searching will not work for some collection codes

comments.body: @regineheberlein Is there a small decimal point EAD?

Sorry @tpendragon, I'm not understanding your question. We have a few dozen EAD files with decimal points in the collection code / file name, including those with two decimal points (e.g. MC001.02.01 etc.)
@regineheberlein We need to index one, but all the ones I saw are too big and ASpace's QA is crashing when I grab them. Is there one that isn't very big but has a decimal?
@tpendragon Ah, got it. Try MC001.02.06 or MC001.02.06--both around 500MB, and they have an inventory (i.e. not collection-level only).

pulfalight.title: Notes at parent level(s) should filter down to child components

comments.body: @faithc We're having a hard time figuring out how to work this ticket. Can you find an example in the staging site where it's showing notes it shouldn't, or not showing a note it should so we can make this actionable? Even a new issue per note would be super helpful.
Maybe https://github.com/pulibrary/pulfalight/issues/286 is the documentation for this and we just need to do that work first?
Yes. The data in the spreadsheet explains how collection-level notes should be managed. Thanks.
Actually, @regineheberlein, does the encoding that we included in the spreadsheet still apply now that we're talking about ASpace records?
@faithc No, that needs to be revised--it'll be wrong especially for the descgrp cases.

pulfalight.title: Implement collection-level badges indicating the access permissions for the resource

comments.body: @sdellis Can you point us towards logic or describe how we should be indexing access permissions based on component info?

@tpendragon I think I can describe it, and these rules go all the way up to the collection level: 

- When a parent component's children are all restricted (aka, `<accessrestrict type="closed">`), the component should get a "Restricted Content" indicator.
- When a parent component's children have at least one restricted child, the component should get a "Some Restricted Content" indicator.
- When a child component has restricted content, it should get a "Restricted Content" indicator.

I recently heard about `<accessrestrict type="review">` in which I believe we haven't yet reviewed the content for access restrictions, but will upon request. Perhaps @apferrar , @faithc, or @regineheberlein can weigh in on what should be shown here... "Possible Restricted Content"?
@sdellis Thanks! I've copied your comment to the root issue and moved it back over from blocked.

@sdellis @tpendragon The only values currently in our EADs are "open", "closed", and "review". This was changed by ADAPT fairly recently. 

In ASpace, both "review" and "closed" will be set to "restrictions=>true" in ASpace ("open" will correspondingly be "restrictions=>false"), with the text of the restriction stored in "notes". On the top_container record, the default value for the type of restriction will most likely be a generic "Restricted"--we're still in the process of working that out with Lyrasis--and the text of the note I believe will be in "active_restrictions".
